paper_name: Finding Global Homophily in Graph Neural Networks When Meeting Heterophily
method_summary: The proposed models GloGNN and GloGNN++ develop an effective way to generalize graph neural networks (GNNs) for handling graphs with heterophily. Both models aggregate node embeddings by utilizing information from global nodes within the entire graph rather than just local neighborhoods, which is typical in traditional GNNs. In each layer of GloGNN, a coefficient matrix is learned that captures inter-node correlations, thus facilitating a more robust neighborhood aggregation. These models accelerate computations through a linear time complexity and derive closed-form solutions for the coefficient matrix, avoiding direct computation that could result in cubic and quadratic complexities. The models emphasize the 'grouping effect,' ensuring nodes with similar features are represented closely in the embedding space.
experiment_summary: The experiments conducted assessed the performance of GloGNN and GloGNN++ against 11 competing methods across 15 benchmark datasets of varying sizes and heterophilies. The results demonstrated that both GloGNN and GloGNN++ outperformed competitors in terms of classification accuracy and efficiency, particularly emphasizing their capability to handle diverse graph structures effectively.
